Hi Aidan,

The original reference implementation of the 'hard' learning pro=
blem is available (with source) from:
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html=

(In the novelty search c++ package).

The file "hard_maze.txt" included wi=
th the software is the description file of the maze that includes the exact=
 placement and size of the walls. The exact size and speed of the robot are=
 provided in the source.

The file format is not especially intuitive, but =
I can explain it or supply you with a svg line drawing version that you can=
 use if you'd like.

I agree with Jean-Baptiste in that the exact implement=
ation is not important, the maze just needs to be sufficiently deceptive su=
ch that the gradient of fitness is mostly useless, and the time limit chose=
n such that the maze must be efficiently navigated to reach the goal.

Good=
 luck with your experiments, I am interested to see what you are
working on=
.

Joel 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Aidan Morgan" <aidos@...> wrote:
>
=
> Hi Jean-Baptiste,
> 
> Thankyou for your feedback. 
> 
> I was mainly wri=
ting to make sure that I wasn't making any wrong assumptions about how the =
experiment should be performed.
> 
> I am glad to see that I am not far off=
 the mark when it comes to my implementation of the same problem space. 
> =

> I understand that it is relatively irrelevant how I have implemented it =
as long as I use the same implementation for each of the comparison impleme=
ntations, however I just wanted to make sure I wasn't making wildly unjusti=
fied assumptions.
> 
> Thankyou for the link to your paper, I found it very=
 interesting and now have another implementation that I can use to compare/=
validate my ideas. Hopefully I will be able to get to IROS this year and wi=
ll see you there :-).
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> Aidan
> 
> 
>   ----- Original Mess=
age ----- 
>   From: mandor@... 
>   To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
>   Sent: Mo=
nday, September 21, 2009 7:23 PM
>   Subject: Re: [neat] Reproducing the "h=
ard" learning problem
> 
> 
>     Hi,
> 
>   "Aidan Morgan" <aidos@...> wro=
te :
> 
>   | I am trying to replicate the "hard" learning problem from the=

>   | behavioural diversity papers that have recently been discussed on
> =
  | the mailing list. I have a few ideas I would like to try out, but I
>  =
 | would like to be able to compare them to the original research to
>   | =
see if I can get any improvement.
> 
>   | I have two questions to ask of t=
hose of you who have tried
>   | recreating this:
> 
>   I have recreated i=
t in a slightly different setup (the change were
>   made to simplify the i=
mplementation in my framework and the potential
>   implementation on a rea=
l robot). In my experience, the results were
>   easy to reproduce and does=
 not depends much on the details.
> 
>   For details about my implementatio=
n, you can check the paper that I
>   will present at the IROS workshop ("E=
xploring new horizons of
>   Evolutionary Design of Robots", see the next m=
essage):
>   http://chronos.isir.upmc.fr/~mouret/papers/novelty_based_multi=
objectivization.pdf
> 
>   | 1. How big is the area? I have got all of the =
internal "walls" in
>   | place in scale to the total size of the map, howe=
ver I would like to
>   | get a rough idea of the width/height of the "map"=
. I understand that
>   | this should all be relative, but without some sor=
t of "scale factor"
>   | for my map from the original I don't know what is=
 a reasonable
>   | amount of space for the agent to move etc. Currently my=
 world is 120
>   | x 115 units big, and the agent can move anywhere up to =
2.5 units per
>   | time period.
> 
>   My hard map is 500x500 px, that are=
 transformed into a 600x600 units
>   maze. The radius of my robot is 20 un=
its. Each wheel can make up 2
>   units per time step and I used 1500 time-=
steps for the whole
>   simulation.
> 
>   | 2. I also am interested in how=
 the outputs of the neural network are
>   | interpreted. I know from the p=
apers that there are two output
>   | neurons, one for forward/backward and=
 one for left/right. Currently
>   | I am interpreting these as output < 0.=
5 =3D turn left, output > 0.5 =3D
>   | turn right and the same for forward=
/backward. This is leading to a
>   | pretty constant behaviour of moving i=
n circles around the map,
>   | always turning left - so I am wondering how=
 other people have
>   | interpreted the output result to get a more intell=
igent movement
>   | pattern.
> 
>   I used a different robot than in the o=
riginal paper. The main reason
>   was to have outputs similar to the ones =
you could use on a small
>   mobile robot. I have two outputs: 
>   - speed=
 of the right wheel
>   - speed of the left wheel
> 
>   I can send you my =
source code in you think it can be useful. 
> 
>   Best regards,
>   -- 
> =
  Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
>   http://animatlab.lip6.fr/~mouret
>   te=
l : (+33) 6 28 35 10 49
>
